content: From the Rodale book, Symptoms, Their Causes & Cures:

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td a span
html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div h1 span
html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div p font b span
html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div p span
content: * Someone informs you that you've had a brief staring spell during which you were unresponsive and you have no memory of the episode.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div p font b span
content: What Your Symptom Is Telling You

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div p font i span
html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div p span
content: t's normal to stare if a Grace Kelly look-alike sits across from you on the bus. Or to have a vacant, out-to-lunch look when daydreaming about winning the lottery. But what if you've just been told that you've had a brief, fixed, blank stare on your face, you didn't respond to your name and worse, you remember zilch about this staring spell?

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div p span
content: You could have had a mild type of epileptic seizure, according to Allan Krumholz, M.D., professor of neurology at the University of Maryland Medical Center in Baltimore. This type of seizure was formerly called

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div p i span
html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div p span
content: but is now called absence, because people look absentminded, he says.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div p span
content: When a person has an absence seizure, says Dr. Krumholz, they've momentarily lost consciousness because their brain has been taken over by abnormal electrical activity.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div p font b span
html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div p font i span
html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div p span
content: f this is your first staring episode, it's important to see a doctor to identify the cause and start treatment, says Dr. Krumholz. (For more information about the kinds of things your doctor will consider, see Seizures on page 448.)
